comments.commentBody: As a pluralist, I think this treatment of evangelical groups is absurd. Pluralism tolerates religious world views of all kinds. It just says in matters of employment, only merit should be considered, not extrinsic factors like race, gender and relgion. In the case of campus evangelical groups, however, religion is obviously not an extrinsic factor, but an intrinsic factor essential to what makes the elected officeholder worthy of the position. So to me this ruling against evangelical groups is an absurd misapplication of pluralism.
Some secularists are on your side. Don't blow it by adopting a shrill persecution complex. It is that very attitude (Sarah Palin) that makes people want to get rid of you.

All this reaction because the private school won't give official sanction to a student club that flouts the apparently reasonable official policy to which every other such group is required to subscribe? They're free to meet any time they want -- just not on the school's dime.

As an evangelical Christian, I have come to expect this sort of thing, and believe it will get much worse. Pluralists can ultimately only tolerate other pluralists. The rigidity, unreflective hypocrisy, and cocksure certainty of moral superiority exhibited by many who embrace this ideology rivals anything a fundamentalist Christian could come up with. It is, in truth, simply a rival fundamentalism itself.

Please don't put all Christians in the same category. "When all you do is preach hate and intolerance …" not in the church to which I belong.

Did you read the article carefully ? It stated: "mainline Protestant groups have agreed, saying they do not discriminate and do not anticipate that the new policies will cause problems".

I'm guessing that by "preaching hate and intolerance" you mean supporting the idea that "marriage is defined as a union between a man and a woman". (I.e. the cultural norm for most of the world since history began - a pretty low key form of "hate", if you ask me, unlike stoning or hanging gays, the modern policy in another religion)

You also probably hold up one man's personal family cult, Westboro Baptist Church, to be the exemplar of Christian thought. That would be like holding up Jeffery Daumer as an example of a gay man - utterly ridiculous. Unfortunately, while the average Christian doen't actually hate gays at all, even if they disagree with changing the definition of marriage, at least 155 NYT readers gave a thumbs up to your post about hating and detesting Christians.

As an atheist, that bothers me. Blind hatred of groups that don't toe your own current ideological line on everything is so religious.

Ethan, but I think that exactly the same rule could apply to those of us who are liberal atheists. If we are intolerant towards others, how does that solve the problem of their intolerance towards us?

I have personally experienced more hatred, bigotry, and intolerance from religion than from any other source and I don't think I'm alone in that. But I don't see how adding my hatred and intolerance to the mix wouldl make that better, rather than worse. It seems to me that we should lead by example, rather than adopting the tactics of the opposition.

In spite of the intricate theologies of a thousand religions, the most basic essential truth is, "what goes around, comes around." When all you do is preach hate and intolerance toward others, there is no need to be surprised when others hate and detest you.

Perhaps if Christians were nicer to others, others would be nicer to them.

Ya think?

Typical Evangelical hogwash. You stand rational arguments on their head and then wonder why people treat your head like your bottom.

Higher educational institutions have an obligation to their students to treat everyone as much the same as possible. Not doing so leaves them liable to lawsuits and expensive reparations.

There comes a time in every culture when extremism is either moderated or marginalized. It couldn't happen a moment to soon to evangelicals. Perhaps our country will be able to repair its social institutions and move forward once again.

Here is a link to an NBC video of Jerad Miller at the Bundy Ranch:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4LV3rwdEN80

What part of "well regulated militia" does the gang of 5 on the Supreme Court not understand?

How did Miller and his wife get their arsenal that they used *before* they took the two police officers' guns?

It would have been interesting to work at least one of those SCOTsmen into the theme...Nice, but NEE CIGAR!!

;o)

Ms. Klawitter, made it very Plaid to see in her PASSING Fancy grid, by including TWO rather well-known SCOTsmen, Bell and Carnegie, the former was a Ringer, and the latter was a real Steel!

MOAT eleven!

Howie TBoQ

I agree that drawing empirical conclusions on scant sampling data is not a good idea.
Nor is the assumption that there would be attacks every week, as if that represented some kind of calculus. The human factor always plays a role, especially in the timing.
Now, look over the last 24 months. How many of those months do you think passed without some form of anti government or anti-humanity incident, empowered by possession of a gun.
Sad, very sad that two cops and Mr. Wilcox were murdered in cold blood. Mr. Wilcox had a gun to no avail. He spoke to the murderers instead of killing them. Big mistake.

No, they don't, by their constant insinuations and innuendos, about the present government and those who support it, they give aid and comfort to those who advocate the violent overthrow of this government.  They advocate anarchy.

The pepper spray guy was apparently a hired student guard, and he got the shooter when the shooter stopped to reload.  I'm not saying he was not brave, but he carefully picked his time to act, *after* the shooter had gotten off a number of shots, not while the shooter was still firing.  That is a *big* difference.  If the shooter in Seattle had used a 100 round magazine, then what?

Martin, I am in awe of your knowledge of trivia.

"The 17th century Catholic Church actually declared beavers to be a fish according to dietary restrictions, meaning they are ok to eat on both Fridays and throughout Lent. Beaver meat was a common dish by Native Americans and French settlers to America, so the decision was believed to be important to these people’s behaviors. The church decisions are based more on an animal’s environment than their physical characteristics."

I married a Catholic and Charles is a Catholic. They will believe anything the Pope says (as long as it has to do with Faith) but I doubt either will buy that. So I really think it's a French thing. We both know how nuts they are.

You don't say whether or not you looked on an exchange for a different carrier that offered a better deal.  Even if the Portland you hale from is in Oregon (worst web roll out in the nation), the information was out there.  Did you do your homework?  bc

The web non-rollout did not keep thousands of people from applying for exchange coverage. The real point here is that most of the cancelled policies DID offer real, high-value coverage, they just didn't offer first-dollar coverage, and neither do the ACA plans. People still have to pay for care, there isn't really any free care. Consider it as pre-paid.

I am an outspoken supporter of Obamacare, and yet I must once again correct the misconception that canceled policies were replaced by something better. My insurance carrier canceled my pre-Obamacare policy and replaced it with one that costs me 40% more in premiums and charges me higher co-pays for everything under the sun. The total out-of-pocket deductible is lower, but I more than make up for that by the higher premiums and higher everything else. One medication I was prescribed monthly for a sinus condition went from a $15 co-pay to $122. And no, this is not because I want a brand name; it is because a generic does not exist.

Suffice to say I now do without that medication.

It's important to be comfortable with oneself, because that is the only company anyone can count on.  In life, I've seen friends get caught up in their own lives, romances end, family time going to managing illness.  I still remember, nearly twenty years ago, being a new driver and taking myself out to a restaurant alone.  I got over feeling self-conscious and relaxed, daydreaming while I waited for lunch.  I got into the groove and spent the rest of the day out by myself.  When I came home, I announced my discovery that I could have fun alone.  In time, I also found that it's much more lonely to be in the presence of a person you're not connecting with than to be with yourself.

Question:

What is the least amount of points a player must score in a row over the course of the game in order to win?

Example A: If player 1 scores 21 points in a row, then she wins with 21.
Example B: If player 1 scores 13 in a row, then player 2 scores 11, then player 1 scores 8 in a row to win, player 1 won with 13 in a row.

What the blank do these people want?   Nothing is going to satisfy them.  Give them full control of the northwest province - that did not satisfy them.  They seem to think they can take control of the whole of Pakistan. What rights do they have over anything outside of northwest province?  The answer is none.  Those are not "their" people.  The ethnic history of the Taliban were never connected to those areas of Pakistan.  It is really quite puzzling.

Pakistan has been a hot bed of major massacres for a lot longer than we've been in Afghanistan.  Pre 9-11 the Sunnis would machine gun a Shia mosque with startling regularity.  My reaction to this story is a little bit of relief that the best the Taliban can do is hit their own country.  Their ability to hit valuable targets outside of their immediate area SEEMS to be extremely curtailed. One attack elsewhere could change that but we can't be expected to fix Pakistan's problems.  We can help Pakistan and we should but we can't make long-seeded issues disappear.
Oops-- that should read "a tired trope" or, if you prefer, "tired tripe".
Netliner, I like the phrase grim satisfaction. It gets to the contradictory nature of the column. Tripe seems to have the essence more accurately labeled.
Tripe is a pretty good  description too!

I take some grim satisfaction in that at least a few conservatives are waking up to the fact that the unfettered market is not creating bounty for all.

But the belief that liberals impose "big government" is a tired tripe. Progressives support community-based enterprise and social entrepreneurship with local control these days.

Gullible? Let's hope that explains it. Otherwise it gets even scarier than the headlines celebrating the boldness and power of the bad guys, whomever they might be.

Excellent post, thank you.
that's a good point.  Why not just refurbish all the old ones?
Very good points... but the average reader doesn't know the differences you speak of - sadly.
It's true that speech as consequences, but those responsible will never have to pay them and they know it.
When do we start calling this what it is: domestic terrorism?
Probably something like this:  There just weren't enough guns in the pizza parlor.  If everyone there had had a gun on his/her hip they would have been more likely to stop the Millers.

The "Weather Underground" made a point of not killing people (even though there were some early thoughts that would have caused many casualties).  The protests were definitely radical left, but they generally caused few civilian deaths.  The ironic part is that few people remember that movement, and I'm not sure if anyone of them actually went to prison.  Killing non-threatening police officers is absurd.  The two involved from "white power" sympathizers from Lafayette, Indiana, not really feeling like they were the radical left - despite how they will be presented in the media.
Last I checked I didn't think Maryland had "open-carry", and concealed carry was pretty difficult.  Maryland is a wild, crazy place, just not at the Home Depot :)

My point is that three "good guys" with guns are dead. Looks like the "good guy with a gun" rule is a huge fallacy. Like Ronald Reagan--lots of good guys with guns all around and he still gets shot.

How about we try and limit the amount of weaponry we have in this country. The way we're doing it now is OBVIOUSLY not working. In fact, it's idiotic.
